snippet: Buying less Iranian oil would further tighten the economic vise on an increasingly defiant nation that announced plans for a new round of naval drills in the Strait of Hormuz.
abstract: Some of Asia's largest economies, including China and Japan, are reluctantly looking for options to reduce the amount of oil they purchase from Iran due to growing pressure from the United States; move would further tighten the economic vise on an increasingly defiant Iran.

byline.original: By KEITH BRADSHER and CLIFFORD KRAUSS
byline.contributor: Keith Bradsher reported from Hong Kong, and Clifford Krauss from Houston. Steven Lee Myers contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Buying less Iranian oil would further tighten the economic vise on an increasingly defiant nation that announced plans for a new round of naval drills in the Strait of Hormuz.

headline.seo: Asian Customers of Iran Look for Other Oil Sources
headline.main: Pressed by U.S., Asian Countries Look for Ways to Reduce Purchases of Iranian Oil
headline.print_headline: Pressed by U.S., Asian Countries Look for Ways to Reduce Purchases of Iranian Oil
